Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is for a new REU site at North Carolina State University. It is focused on training undergraduates in software engineering, particularly in skills related to data analytics. Data analytics has become increasingly important in how companies and researchers make decisions about improving the reliability and usability of software.

The intention of the project is to give research exposure and training to a diverse group of undergraduate students. The project aims at building students' analytical skills as well as research skills with the goal of leading them toward a research career in future. The project will primarily recruit women and minorities through the STARs alliance and from non-PhD granting universities.

The project covers various areas of software engineering including visualization and data manipulation in virtual reality, model-based reasoning, human aspects (e.g., eye tracking data), bug fixing, and software analytics which is a cross between software and data mining methods. The overall research theme will investigate how to take advantage of qualitative organizational knowledge which gives data its context and meaning integrated with quantitative data mining methods that support exploration of large and complex datasets.

The project will encourage the students to disseminate their research findings through presentations as well as publishing in research venues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a NSF sponsored Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site, the Science of Software at North Carolina State University, sought to engage undergraduate researchers in data analytics applied to meaningful software engineering research problems. The REU site's goals included preparing participants in advanced graduate study and STEM careers in software engineering, applying qualitative and quantitative research skills to solve software engineering problems, enhancing the diversity of the computing research pipeline, and disseminating research results. Faculty mentors trained the participants to be researchers and provided them with specialized training in the design and execution of empirical studies. This specialized training provides the students with research skills that will benefit them in future pursuits in research and industry.


The REU site has supported 45 participants, successfully recruiting female, underrepresented, and first-generation college students, including participants from institutions without PhD programs. The REU Site achieved these goals in connecting undergraduate participants with faculty mentors in their in ongoing research projects, cultivating the talents of the participants via parallel series of intensive research training sessions and professional development seminars/workshops, and encouraging the participants to pursue graduate study through close mentoring during and after the summer programs. 
Key outcomes include alumni and graduate student mentors who went on to work in prestigious academic or industry research positions, a Rhodes Scholar Finalist, a Churchill Scholarship Finalist, pursue a PhD students at University of Florida, and several returning to North Carolina State University to purse a PhD. Other alumni have taken software engineering positions at companies such as Google, Amazon, IBM, and MITRE.

The REU site has been successful in preparing students for graduate work and dissemination. Several students submitted their work to the Student Research Competitions, including ACM Joint European Software Engineering Conference and Symposium on the Foundations of Software Engineering (ESEC/FSE) and ACM SIGPLAN conference on Systems, Programming, Languages and Applications: Software for Humanity (SPLASH). Multiple participants have had their paper accepted, attended the conferences (2016--2018), and won prizes, including first place. Participants have also published work in top-tier conferences, including the International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE), International Conference on Mining Software Repositories (MSR), the International Conference Automated Software Engineering (ASE).
